title: Race becomes an issue in jury selection for ex-NFL star Kellen Winslow II
text:
CLOSE

VISTA, Calif. — In an effort to seat a jury here for the retrial of Kellen Winslow II, a pool of 172 prospective jurors recently was summoned to court from a variety of different age groups and occupations.

There was a retired soccer coach, a grocery store cashier and a general counsel for a local company, among dozens of others. But only four of the 172 were African-Americans, leading Winslow’s attorneys to raise the issue of their client’s ability to get a fair trial.

Winslow, a former NFL star, is African-American. He is about to stand trial on charges of raping or sodomizing three different women who are white or Asian.

“There should be more African-Americans,” one of Winslow’s attorneys, Gretchen von Helms, told the judge last week.

Of the first 86 prospective jurors summoned to court last week, only one was African-American.

“To have only one African-American is appalling,” von Helms said to the judge. “It is not representative.”

HIGH STAKES, TOUGH QUESTIONS: In Kellen Winslow II's second rape trial

MORE WINSLOW: How Kellen Winslow II went from NFL star to accused serial rapist

Kellen Winslow II appears in court in Vista, Calif., on the first day of his rape trial. (Photo: John Gibbins, AP)

This is the second trial on rape charges for Winslow, 36. In the first, a jury of eight men and four women – none African-American – convicted him in June of raping a white homeless woman, exposing himself to a Vietnamese neighbor down the street and lewd conduct with another Asian woman at a local gym, all ages 57 or older. Those convictions still stand and could put him behind bars for nine years. But that jury couldn’t reach a unanimous verdict on most of the other charges as required, setting up a retrial with a new 12-person jury being selected here this week.

This is the same court in north San Diego County where Winslow stood trial the first time. It draws its jury pool from near where the alleged crimes occurred. It also is near where Winslow had a $3 million home in Encinitas, an upscale seaside community where African-Americans make up less than 1% of the population, according to government data. Other parts of north San Diego County also are heavily white, with few communities having populations where African-Americans make up more than 5%.

“There really aren’t that many African-Americans in those parts of town,” said M. Dod Ghassemkhani, a criminal defense attorney not involved in this case.

Across the nation, the underrepresentation of African-Americans on juries still remains an issue with complex causes and no easy solutions. In this case, Winslow is facing life in prison if convicted of more forcible sex crimes. On Monday, von Helms also noted this was a case in which white women had accused a black man of rape and that there was a stream of “white juror after white juror” coming through the jury screening process.

At one point, one prospective African-American juror also became a subject of conflict between Winslow’s attorneys and prosecutor Dan Owens. The woman told the judge Monday she once lived down the street from Winslow’s family in the early 1980s and indicated she might view the Winslows favorably in deliberations over his guilt.

Because of this, Owens wanted her excused from the case on the grounds that it indicated she might not be fair and impartial. But Winslow’s attorneys wanted to keep her.

“I should mention to the court: We have an issue here in that we have (approximately) 180 jurors ... and we’ve got four black people,” Marc Carlos, an attorney for Winslow, told Judge Blaine Bowman.

Von Helms then noted to Bowman the “problem with striking an African-American” from the jury pool.

“Look, I don’t change the standard based on the color of their skin, OK,” Bowman told her. “The same rules apply.”

“As a judge, you have to be careful that it is not, that striking (a juror) for cause is not a proxy for race,” von Helms said.

Von Helms noted racial segregation by neighborhoods in San Diego County and said, “You are not going get other white people living down the street from a black family in the ‘80s.”

This prospective juror said she once lived down the street from the Winslow family in the city of Lemon Grove, which is east of downtown San Diego and not part of the North County jury pool. In 2016, Lemon Grove had around 14% African-Americans, according to estimates.

Bowman decided to reserve judgment on whether the woman should be excused at Owens’ request. Meanwhile, both sides in the case soon hope to seat a jury of 12, plus alternates, with opening statements in the trial likely later this week or next.

Depending on further developments in jury selection, Winslow’s attorneys could invoke Winslow’s right to a jury that represents a fair cross-section of the community. That could mean asking for a whole new jury pool and raising an objection if only to set up a possible appeal.

Both sides last week tried to keep another African-American prospective juror from being excused from the case because of financial hardship. The man indicated last week his employer only covers five days of pay to cover absences because of jury duty. But he had already used two of them, and the trial is expected to last several weeks.

“Would you be able to survive financially without pay for such a long period of time?” Bowman asked the man.

The man replied could use his vacation time to serve on the jury if necessary. Bowman then told him he didn’t meet the financial-hardship requirements to be excused from the case.

description: Racial composition of the jury pool has become a concern as former NFL tight end Kellen Winslow II goes to trial again on rape charges
